title: Fast food in runeterra?
body:
I generally count fast food as a pretty modern thing, and would associate it with some of the more modern societies in league lore, like Piltover. Recently learned I'm wrong about that, it's historically present in some form and even ancient Rome had fast food ( https://www.smithsonianmag.com/smart-news/romans-loved-fast-food-much-we-do-180971845/ for the interested). This got me wondering about fast food in Runeterra. Could Galio really be serving fried chicken in Demacia? Is Shurima into pizza enough to warrent Sivir's violent delivery methods? Do noxian happy meals have spikes on their boxes, and do those have a mortality rate if so? (weeding out the weak)

(generically qualifying fast food as drive-thru/quick takeout style food, although open to discussion about the bounds of that definition) 

What kinds of fast food do you think are popular in the different areas of Runeterra?

replies.body:
I like this topic.

I think that, historically, 'fast' or street food was present less because people were in a hurry and had disposable money to spend on premade food, as it was about the fact that running an oven or other intensive cooking setup was very expensive and the majority of homes in many places and times did not have one.

That's why it used to be that bread was baked in a central oven in a settlement, rather than each home baking their own.  Having an oven was a big investment, took a long time to get up to heat (which meant a lot of expensive fuel) and generally would only be used a few times a week - thus, not worth.

So look to nations where fuel would be expensive or hard to get a hold of, or where living situations favor smaller homes, or where heat (ovens generate a lot of it) is highly undesirable within the living spaces.

Without looking at my notes (which I've got a bunch of - we did a Thunderdome) I'd say look to:

* **Piltover**: Apartment living is a thing, and having an oven in every apartment would be crazy.  Also, it's a big city so getting fuel would be expensive.
* **Zaun**: Similar problem with the added fun of open flames and smoke adding fun times in the often-smoggy, frequently-affected-by-gas-leaks, lower tiers.
* **Shurima**: In the cities at least, communal cooking would probably be a thing, especially where fuel would be difficult to find.
* **Bilgewater**: Populated by boom-and-bust workers unlikely to have a stable home situation, there are probably food options for every price range, depending on how your last monster hunt, theft, or trade went down.

That is something I hadn't considered at all, very interesting! How much of a stigma is there for eating sea monsters in a place like bilgewater? 

Also, what's your opinion on Ionia's ff choices? After another comment pointed out instant ramen and I did some quick googling. Found out stir-fry and other modern Asian food is relatively new, more ming-dynasty and on kinda stuff, while older Asian culture was more into boiling, roasting, and stews. Stews tend to make good "community food", but it's also a very "sit down and eat for a while" kind of thing, so I'm not sure how much they qualify for this topic.

(There are a few more on Universe and the Runeterra map)

Folks native to the Serpent Isles probably have a _significantly_ more varied diet (to tie into another thread, Illaoi loves her mangoes) and the consumption of sea monster is probably more meaningful to them than your typical Bilgewater scrub.

Harder to speak to Ionia, seeing as it has such a variety of living situations, biomes, resources, etc.  Getting fuel might be tricky or at least, wasting it may be very looked down upon, as most fuel types we're used to seeing are wood, coal, or dried dung - and the first two of those don't seem very in harmony with the land (except for fallen wood, but cooking uses a lot of fuel).  They may be more into magically cooked food, solar cooking, chemically cooked food (acids like lemon juice or vinegar), fermentation, drying, and the like.  In other words, it's less clear cut than some of the other comparable locations, imo.

I see, I figured them more for fish based diets with sea monsters only during big hauls, but from your wording it sounds like they fit more into the pre-historic man type setup, where you hunt something big and eat it for a while, then hunt again.

As an odd pedantic question, where do you draw the line between sea monster and fish? I feel like it's a size thing, like when the thing is large enough to eat a person or two. But then I realize a tuna fish can get up to 1,500 lbs, and I don't really consider tuna to be sea monsters whereas an Anglerfish is ~100 lbs and would probably qualify as one to me. Is it just how ugly they are? 

 Is Ionia overwhelmingly vegan then? I didn't realize they were far enough on the scale to not cut down trees as fuel, and that vastly limits food options. Can they eat beans for their daily protein?

Some may well be, others not so much - there are stories of animals 'offering themselves' as they emerge from the ocean in droves ready to be caught and eaten.  With Ionia, it's tricky to work out the line between what is actually magic and what is nature, so I personally don't know if the spirit of Ionia is offering up the creatures as a reward for living in harmony, if it's a natural phenomenon when populations of the creatures get too high (due to favorable conditions) or if there's some other mechanism at work.
There are likely other groups of Ionians who hunt for food (we know there are Ionians who hunt for protection - see the Varus comics) but do so in a way that reinforces the natural order, rather than upsetting it.
Lastly, not everyone in Ionia is successfully living in harmony with the land.  I'm sure there are some who kill and eat what they please, and to hell with the consequences, maybe due to a lack of education, lack of options, or as intentional snub to the old ways.

That is some grade A animal wingmanning right there. "hey mate, I see you've got a date tonight. Imma just hop out of the water here so you two can have some fish tonight!" 

Regional differences definitely are going to play a big part in fast food choice. I would see bilgewater as being one of the more homogenized states, whereas I think an area like Demacia would be much more regional in their food. Ionia would have some decent variance due to their varied environment maybe, but with its size I'm not sure that will be the limit. Education definitely would be though. Does Ionia have squirrel-eating rednecks out there in the outskirts of the forest markets?

If Ionians dont cut down trees ... 
I do not want to live in Ionia during the winter.

What about pinecones and chestnuts that can be replanted? assuming deciduous trees are native to Ionia that is.
But Noxus has _Tacos_.

You'd rather buy supplies that last long on your journey through the desert, and not something to eat right away. Most fast food also spoils very fast.

Bilgewater - maybe.

Ixtal, Freljord, Targon, Ionia - nah.

Only other thing I really disagree on is bulge water. Especially in the context of some of the stuff in the Smithsonian link, I really think bilgewater would have a thriving fast food setup with fish markets and the tapas-style servings.

I assume you meant ming dynasty? It would still be pretty far back since the dynasty fell in 1644, 400 years ago. Also, I think noodle got smaller as the year went on, not bigger; after all, the ability to make them thinner only came later with the development of techniques and later the machines (Northern Chinese food still prides itself of making their own noodle by hand, tho, and their noodle is a lot thicker than the ones made from a factory).

The "fast food" of Ancient China wouldn't be like today's take-away menu. Depending on the region within China but it would probably be something like getting steamed buns and take it with you, communal township eating place of sort where you sit and eat very casually, or small food stands that typically provide very casual food like giving you a bowl of watery rice or soy milk and you finish it there and return the bowl and move on.

People have been selling food that can either eat on the go or you sit in the shed and finish it in 3 min, for a long time already. In the western world there's the Ancient Rome's Thermopolium that is basically a fast food store that sold ready-to-eat food and funnily enough Ancient Rome were also the first inventors of hamburgers (soz Americans). Then you get quickie street food stalls that's one of the staples in Asian food culture which dates back however long. And I'm sure most cultures should have that sort of thing at least at some point in time.

Such infrastructure was often necessary because there needed to be ways to feed the hungry labouring force quickly (miners, fishers, sailors, etc; though for positions such as farmers, foragers and foresters, typically they have people who send food to the field so it's more about pre-modern UberEats than it is fast food), but also ofc being the money savvy many people are they were quick to set up businesses to cater to the demand and thus gave birth to fast food.

All in all, fast food _joint/chain_ is modern, yes; but fast food as a _concept_, no not really.
